channel.title: NYT > World
channel.copyright: Copyright 2013 The New York Times Company

item.title: Experts Say Poaching Could Soon Lead to a Decline in the Rhino Population
item.description: Economics is driving the destruction of the animals in Africa and Asia, where the horns are seen as luxury items.
item.category: Far East, South and Southeast Asia and Pacific Areas
item.dc:creator: By LOUIS LUCERO II
item.media:description: A sedated rhinoceros at a ranch near Johannesburg. Two rhinos a day are said to be poached in South Africa alone.

item.title: Kerry Opposes Afghan Delay on Security Deal
item.description: President Hamid Karzai’s threat not to sign the pact until next year threatened relations between Washington and Kabul, a State Department spokeswoman said.
item.dc:creator: By STEVE KENNY

item.title: Urbanites Flee China’s Smog for Blue Skies
item.description: China is undergoing a surprising reverse migration: As millions leave to find work in the cities, some well-educated urban dwellers are relocating to small towns.
item.dc:creator: By EDWARD WONG
item.media:credit: Gilles Sabrie for The New York Times
item.media:description: Zheng Yuantao, 33, a translator, moved to Dali, a town in southwest China, from Beijing in July. “I’ve never felt so free in my life.”

item.title: Pentagon Releases Strategy for Arctic
item.description: Speaking at a security forum, Defense Secretary Chuck Hagel outlined the United States’ priorities and concerns, like economic competition and melting ice caps, in the region.
item.dc:creator: By THOM SHANKER

item.title: North Korea Confirms It Is Holding U.S. Citizen
item.description: North Korea’s confirmation broke nearly four weeks of silence by the country’s authorities about the detained American, Merrill Newman, 85, of Palo Alto, Calif.
item.dc:creator: By RICK GLADSTONE
item.media:credit: Nicholas Wright/Palo Alto Weekly, via Associated Press
item.media:description: Merrill Newman in 2005. Mr. Newman, 85, has been detained by North Korea since last month.

item.title: Iran Would Eliminate Stock of Some of Its Enriched Uranium Under Deal
item.description: Western officials say a proposed agreement would force the dilution or other conversion of 20 percent enriched uranium.
item.dc:creator: By STEVEN ERLANGER

item.title: Political Doubt Poses Risk to Honduras, Battered by Coup and Violence
item.description: Just four years from a coup, the elections for president and Congress on Sunday promise to be close, raising concerns that the losing parties may not honor the results.
item.category: Coups D'Etat and Attempted Coups D'Etat
item.dc:creator: By ELISABETH MALKIN

item.title: A Gamble in Iran Talks: Easing of the Sanctions
item.description: President Obama’s critics — in Congress, the Arab world and Israel — argue that he has the strategy backward in negotiating a freeze of Iran’s nuclear program.
item.dc:creator: By DAVID E. SANGER and JODI RUDOREN
item.media:description: Mohammad Javad Zarif is Iran’s foreign minister and chief negotiator in talks on his country’s nuclear program.

item.title: World Briefing | Asia: Japan: Governor of Tokyo Embroiled in Loan Scandal
item.description: The governor of Tokyo, Naoki Inose, received a half-million dollars from a hospital operator involved in an election-fraud case.
item.dc:creator: By MARTIN FACKLER

item.title: World Briefing | Europe: Russia: Most of Greenpeace Crew Have Now Been Released on Bail
item.description: All but one of the 30 people arrested after a Greenpeace protest against oil drilling in the Arctic were free on bail Friday after spending more than two months in Russian jails.
item.category: International Tribunal for the Law of the Sea
item.dc:creator: By THE ASSOCIATED PRESS

item.title: Norwegian, 22, Takes World Chess Title
item.description: Magnus Carlsen, a 22-year-old Norwegian, defeated Viswanathan Anand, 43, of India, the titleholder since 2007, and he did not lose a game in the best-of-12 series.
item.dc:creator: By DYLAN LOEB McCLAIN
item.media:description: Magnus Carlsen of Norway, right, greeted Viswanathan Anand of India before their final game on Friday in Chennai, India.

item.title: World Briefing | Middle East: Iraq: At Least 23 Die in Attacks
item.description: No group claimed responsibility for the attacks, which struck several neighborhoods in Baghdad and the cities of Abu Ghraib, Tarmiya and Mosul.
item.dc:creator: By THE ASSOCIATED PRESS

item.title: U.S. Retailers Decline to Aid Factory Victims in Bangladesh
item.description: Walmart, Sears, Children’s Place and other American companies that were selling goods produced at the site of two disasters are not joining in efforts to compensate victims’ families.
item.dc:creator: By STEVEN GREENHOUSE
item.media:description: Rescue workers at the Tazreen fire in 2012.

item.title: Editor in India, Known for Investigations Into Corruption, Is Accused of Rape
item.description: Rape and sexual assault charges have been filed against Tarun Tejpal, the editor of Tehelka, a liberal-minded magazine that has influenced a generation of young Indian journalists.
item.dc:creator: By ELLEN BARRY

item.title: The Saturday Profile: Fighter of Corruption in Nigeria Considers Next Steps
item.description: Nuhu Ribadu, who has been celebrated inside Nigeria and beyond for his five-year tenure as chief of an anticorruption unit, has not ruled out a bid for the presidency.
item.dc:creator: By ADAM NOSSITER
item.media:description: “Up to my last day at work, people were trying to bribe me. That is the shocking thing,” said Nuhu Ribadu.

item.title: Death Toll Rises in Supermarket Collapse in Latvia
item.description: The number of people killed reached 51, and officials said hope was fading for at least 25 more victims believed to be trapped in the rubble.
item.dc:creator: By DAVID M. HERSZENHORN
item.media:description: Police tape cordons off an area around the Maxima supermarket on Friday.

item.title: The Lede: In Taunts From Iran’s Ruler, Some Israelis Hear Echoes of Nazi Propaganda
item.description: As Secretary of State John Kerry noted, what might otherwise have been dismissed as harmless name-calling by Iran’s leader is deeply distressing to some Israelis, since he has previously made “very disturbing assertions regarding the Holocaust.”
item.dc:creator: By ROBERT MACKEY

item.title: Mavis Batey, World War II Code Breaker, Dies at 92
item.description: Mrs. Batey volunteered to be an army nurse after Britain declared war on Germany in 1939, but was instead assigned to the top-secret Allied effort to decipher codes.
item.dc:creator: By DOUGLAS MARTIN
item.media:description: Mavis Lever was assigned to one of World War II's most secret and important operations.

item.title: Questions on Drone Strike Find Only Silence
item.description: Faisal bin Ali Jaber, who lost two relatives in a drone strike, struggled to pierce a veil of secrecy and anonymity during a visit to Washington.
item.dc:creator: By ROBERT F. WORTH and SCOTT SHANE

item.title: Ukraine Blames I.M.F. for Halt to Agreements With Europe
item.description: Ukraine’s prime minister said his government’s decision to walk away from the pacts was based on fiscal imperatives, and ultimately prompted by the I.M.F.’s overly harsh terms for an aid package.
item.dc:creator: By DAVID M. HERSZENHORN
item.media:description: Protesters displayed a European Union flag in Kiev on Friday. A decision to scrap accords with Europe led to rallies throughout Ukraine.

item.title: Wine Cellar, Well Aged, Is Revealed in Israel
item.description: Where rulers of a Middle Bronze Age city-state once feasted, researchers have found one of civilization’s oldest and largest wine cellars.
item.dc:creator: By JOHN NOBLE WILFORD
item.media:description: A storage room unearthed from the ruins of a 1700 B.C. Canaanite palace in northern Israel held the remains of 40 ceramic jars.

item.title: Kerry to Join Iran Nuclear Talks, in Sign of Progress
item.description: Negotiators may be near an accord that would impose a temporary freeze on the country’s nuclear program, but disagreements remain.
item.dc:creator: By MICHAEL R. GORDON

item.title: Powerful Rebel Groups in Syria Announce Creation of Umbrella Alliance
item.description: While some rebels and opposition activists hailed the group’s formation as a major step forward, it remained unclear if it reflected a true reorganization of forces.
item.category: Middle East and North Africa Unrest (2010- )
Islamic State of Iraq and Syria
National Coalition of Syrian Revolutionary and Opposition Forces
item.dc:creator: By BEN HUBBARD and KARAM SHOUMALI

item.title: Toll Confirms Storm Is One of Philippines’ Deadliest
item.description: A jump in the number of dead Friday, to more than 5,200, showed that Typhoon Haiyan had reached the levels of Tropical Storm Thelma in 1991.
item.dc:creator: By AUSTIN RAMZY

item.title: The Lede: Colleagues Remember Journalist Missing for One Year in Syria
item.description: At least 30 journalists are now missing in Syria and believed to have been kidnapped. Fifty-two journalists have been killed since the start of the Syrian conflict in March 2011, and 24 more have been kidnapped but released.
item.category: Middle East and North Africa Unrest (2010- )
item.dc:creator: By LIAM STACK
